Award.AbstractNarration:
A request is made to fund additional and back-up instrumentation for the R/V Hugh R Sharp, a 146 foot Regional research vessel operated as part of the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) research fleet.

The R/V Hugh R Sharp is a state-of-the-art, coastal research vessel that is owned and operated by the University of Delaware. The vessel can carry fourteen to twenty scientists on cruises up to eighteen days in duration, and supports projects from all disciplines of oceanography. The vessel is a regional asset, serving researchers from many institutions throughout the mid-Atlantic. The vessel typically operates in the coastal waters from Long Island, New York, to Cape Hatteras, North Carolina, as well as the Delaware and Chesapeake Bays. Projects occasionally require the vessel to work as far north as the Gulf of Maine, as far south as Florida, and as far offshore as Bermuda. In 2014, the R/V Hugh R Sharp completed 193 days at sea. NSF funded projects accounted for 25% of the total sailing schedule (49 days). In 2015, R/V Hugh R Sharp is scheduled for 200 days with NSF days accounting for 17% (34 days) of the total sailing schedule.

Oceanographic Instrumentation requested in this proposal includes:


Network Time Clock $8,736
UPS Replacement $10,240
Kongsberg HiPAP Tracking System $341,924
Red Box High Capacity Data Storage $17,781
$378,681

Broader Impacts

The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcome Report

 

Intellectual Merit: The awarded equipment will help support scientific operations and data collection in the mid-Atlantic region.  The intellectual merit of these individual projects is determined by peer review at NSF.  The scientific questions posed must be meritorious enough to warrant the funding, and only those few will be fortunate enough to go to sea. 

 

Broader Impacts:  The number of missions supported for the R/V HUGH R. SHARP averages around thirty per year, in the coastal zone.  The science support equipment project herein will enhance the infrastructure required for research and education on the vast majority of those cruises.

 

Award number OCE1523249, “Oceanographic Instrumentation CY2015” was awarded for $26,517 in March 13,2015. These funds were identified to purchase a Red Box Backblaze High Capacity Data Storage system and a SecureSys GPS Network Time Clock for science use aboard the R/V HUGH R. SHARP.

 

Due to technology advancements during the proposal and award process, the Second Red Box Backblaze High Capacity Data Storage system was set aside for a different type storage system. Three Synology Disk Stations DS2415+ systems were purchased with supporting equipment. These allows for the same storage capacity as the Red Box Backblaze High Capacity Storage System with the added feature of allowing science to transport the high capacity data. This system was installed at the beginning of the CY2016 science sailing season. This will benefit all users of the R/V HUGH R. SHARP with high volume data storage requirements such as high definition video, multibeam survey, multibeam backscatter and multibeam water column. This system will also allow the science user to take this high volume data storage back to their home facility for processing and analyzing.

 

The SecureSys GPS Network Clock was installed late summer CY2015. It was interfaced to the shipboard network and synchronizes all shipboard science support computer systems. This has already proved invaluable for science cruise providing this time server support for computer systems and science mission operations. This will benefit all users of the R/V HUGH R. SHARP since all data collected will be properly time synchronized and time stamped.
